table.TableDescription: This table contains information about the different people (parties) involved in your plots, projects, taxa, and classifications.
table.TableReqd: Not required. VegBranch can generate this table from other tables (Plot Data and Plot Community Data).

field.FieldDefinition: Database generated identifier assigned to each unique party.
The Party_ID of this Party that has been migrated into VegBank module.
A unique code that will refer to a party consistently throughout the loading processes.
Name shared in common to identify the members of a family, as distinguished from each member's given name.
One's first name.
One's middle name or initial, if any.
Name of an organization.
Position of party within organization.
email address of party member
Instructions for contacting a party.

field.exampleComments: specify phone number fully
field.FieldDefinition: Telephone number.
This is the type of telephone: home, work, fax, cell, secretary, other.
internal field that reports to VegBranch how the party was matched to VegBank module parties, if applicable.
Address line for the location: for example, Street name, box number, suite.
City of the location.
State, province of the location.
Zip code or other postal code.
Country of the physical address.
This flag signifies whether the address is the current address of the party. "True" is used for addresses that are current.

The first database date on which the address/organization information applied (have a discrete date on which address is known to applied -- not necessarily the first date on which the address applied).

table.TableDescription: This table contains data about plant concepts 1) that you would like to add to VegBank as new concepts and/or 2) to which you would like to add your party perspective.
table.TableReqd: Not required unless you wish to refer to taxa (that is, plant concepts) that are not already in VegBranch.

field.FieldDefinition: Database assigned value for a unique plant record in this table.

field.exampleComments: plant code can be any text string, up to 255 char.
field.FieldDefinition: A code that uniquely identifies a plant taxon in your other loading tables (Cover Data, Stratum Cover, Stem Data). This can be any combination of letters, numbers, spaces, and symbols. It can be a real code, such as a USDA code, or a temporary code, such as a number.
internal VegBranch flag to indicate that this plant record will be added as a new plantConcept to the vegbank module.
internal VegBranch flag to indicate that this plant record will have the current user's party perspective added to the plant record (status, synonyms, different names used, comments, etc.)

field.example2: Acer barbatum Michx. var. longii (Fern.) Fern.
field.exampleComments: VegBranch can look up different types of names. USDA codes, scientific names, and scientific names without authors are best (in that descening order).
field.FieldDefinition: The plant name for which VegBranch will look up the plant in your vegbank module. If the plant name is not found, then the current record will be added as a new plant concept, based on the name in this field.

This is the name of the classification system wherein the current record's plantName is applied (e.g., EnglishCommon or Scientific). This will be migrated to the plantUsage table for all records that have a party perspective added.

This field shows the status of the application of the plantName to the concept by the party (standard, not standard, undetermined). This will be migrated to the plantUsage table for all records that have a party perspective added.

A shorter, alternative Name that corresponds to the current plant Concept record, perhaps lacking authority; an abbreviation. This set of fields (starting with "plantShortName") need not actually be a shorter plant name, but can be any plant name usage to be added to the VegBank module. This will be migrated to the plantUsage table for all records that have a party perspective added.

This is the name of the classification system wherein the plantShortName is applied (e.g., EnglishCommon or Scientific). This will be migrated to the plantUsage table for all records that have a party perspective added.

This field shows the status of the application of the plantShortName to the concept by the party (standard, not standard, undetermined). This will be migrated to the plantUsage table for all records that have a party perspective added.

Another set of fields to add another plant name Usage, perhaps a common name, perhaps not. This set of fields (starting with "plantCommonName") need not actually be a common plant name, but can be any plant name usage to be added to the VegBank module. This will be migrated to the plantUsage table for all records that have a party perspective added.

This is the name of the classification system wherein the plantCommonName is applied (e.g., EnglishCommon or Scientific). This will be migrated to the plantUsage table for all records that have a party perspective added.

This field shows the status of the application of the plantCommonName to the concept by the party (standard, not standard, undetermined). This will be migrated to the plantUsage table for all records that have a party perspective added.

Another set of fields to add another plant name Usage. This set of fields (starting with "otherPlantName") can be any type of plantName to be added to the VegBank module. This will be migrated to the plantUsage table for all records that have a party perspective added.

This is the name of the classification system wherein the otherPlantName is applied (e.g., EnglishCommon or Scientific). This will be migrated to the plantUsage table for all records that have a party perspective added.

This field shows the status of the application of the otherPlantName to the concept by the party (standard, not standard, undetermined). This will be migrated to the plantUsage table for all records that have a party perspective added.

A string (text field) that identifies to you, the user, what reference this plantConcept record will be based upon. You will be prompted to translate this reference string to an actual reference in the VegBank module (or you can add a new reference). Required for all new concepts to be added to VegBank. Will be ignored for all concepts that are matched to VegBank module concepts.

A string (text field) that identifies to you, the user, what reference the plantNames on this record (plantName, plantShortName, plantCommonName, otherPlantName) were originally cited in. You will be prompted to translate this reference string to an actual reference in the VegBank module (or you can add a new reference). Not required, and you can add references to individual names in VegBranch if different references are necessary for the different names on this record.

field.example2: (detailed description of Acer barbatum Michx. var. longii (Fern.) Fern.)
field.exampleComments: this example is not the actual value for the field, but is just a placeholder for the real value that would go here
field.FieldDefinition: The plantDescription is a description of the plantConcept by the party contributing the plantConcept. This is used to provide more information about the plantConcept. Ignored for concepts that are matched to extant VegBank concepts.
The classLevel attribute specifies a level in the taxonomic hierarchy to which the current plantConcept belongs (i.e. family, genus, species). Part of the Party Perspective.

The name of the plantParent for the current plantConcept. A plantParent is part of the Party Perspective and identifies which plantConcept the currentConcept should be nested under in the taxonomic hierarchy. For example if this plantConcept were at the genus level the plantParent would be the plantConcept that is the family level (or subfamily level). The name used here will be looked up in the VegBank module or should reference a PLANTcode of a different record in this table.
Status of the concept by the party (accepted, not accepted, undetermined). Part of the Party Perspective.

field.example1: (Comments by party providing rationale for status assignment)
field.example2: (Comments by party providing rationale for status assignment)
field.exampleComments: this example is not the actual value for the field, but is just a placeholder for the real value that would go here
field.FieldDefinition: Comments by party providing rationale for status assignment in plantConceptStatus. Part of the Party Perspective.
This is the foreign key into the plantConcept table "pointing" to a concept recognized by the party as a "standard" concept.
This is the descriptive attribute that is used to relate the congruence between two concepts.
This is the foreign key into the plantConcept table "pointing" to a concept recognized by the party as a "standard" concept.
This is the descriptive attribute that is used to relate the congruence between two concepts.
This is the foreign key into the plantConcept table "pointing" to a concept recognized by the party as a "standard" concept.
This is the descriptive attribute that is used to relate the congruence between two concepts.
This is the foreign key into the plantConcept table "pointing" to a concept recognized by the party as a "standard" concept.
This is the descriptive attribute that is used to relate the congruence between two concepts.
internal field which shows the status of migration process.

table.TableDescription: This table contains data that are consistent across a plot. For example, elevation, plot name, plot location, etc.
table.TableReqd: REQUIRED. You must have plot data to submit a plot. If you don't have this data in digital format, you will need to enter your plot data manually in a form (see below).

field.FieldDefinition: Database generated identifier assigned to each unique plot/observation.
Link to the parent plot when plot is nested within another plot.
Author's Plot number/code, or the original plot number if taken from literature.

field.exampleComments: pl-44 is a subplots of pl-33 (which would be either already in Vegbank module or in another record in this table, not shown in examples)
field.FieldDefinition: Code that refers to the AuthorPlotCode of the parent plot (this record's plot is a subplot of this ParentAuthPlotCode).

field.exampleComments: optional - must look up the citation_ID from the citation table if you want to use this.
field.FieldDefinition: Link to the source citation from which this plot record was taken
Latitude of the plot origin in degrees and decimals, datum =WGS84
Longitude of the plot origin in degrees and decimals, datum = WGS84
Estimated accuracy of the location of the plot. Plot origin has a 95% or greater probability of being within this many meters of the reported location.

Are the data to be considered confidential? 0=no, 1= 1km radius, 2=10km radius, 3=100km radius, 4=location embargo, 5=public embargo on all plot data, 6=full embargo on all plot data. This applies also to region.
The reason for confidentiality. This field should not be open to public view. Reasons might include specific rare species, ownership, prepublication embargo, or many other reason
Original E-W coordinate as recorded by the author
Original N-S coordinate as recorded by the author
Original UTM zone reported by the author
Original datum reported by the author
Original location as described by author (eg Town-Range-Section)

field.example1: Go to end of XXX St., then proceed north along trail for 200m. Plot is 35m...
field.FieldDefinition: Text description that provides information useful for plot relocation.

This element stores the azimuth of the x-axis used to describe the relative coordinate system for plot shape (dsgpoly) and other spatial information about the plot. Typically the azimuth is parallel to the long axis of the plot (in the case of a rectangle).

This field is a text string containing the points circumscribing a plot area. These points are anticipated to have been collected using tapes, GPS, or calculated from the plot shape and area. Points are x-y coordinates in m relative to plot origin.
Shape of the plot area.
Total area of the plot in m2. If many subplots, this area includes the subplots and the intersticial space
The extent of this community occurrence in relation to the plot size: very extensive (>1000x plot), extensive (>100x plot), large (10-100x plot), small (3-10x plot), very small (1-3x plot).
Brief description of strategy for determining plot placement within the stand.
Is the plot monumented so as to assure permanence? If so, this should be described in the layoutNarrative

field.example1: chose a square plot that resulted from a random azimuth selection
field.FieldDefinition: Text description of and the rationale for the layout of the plot.
The elevation of the plot origin in meters above sea level.
The accuracy of the elevation in percentage of the elevation reported.
Meters of difference in elevations of the high and low points in the plot.
Representative azimuth of slope gradient (0-360 degrees); if too flat to determine = -1; if too irregular to determine = -2.
Minimum azimuth of slope gradient (0-360 degrees), counterclockwise from representative azmuth.
Maximum azimuth of slope gradient (0-360 degrees), clockwise from representative azmuth
Representative inclination of slope in degrees; if too irregular to determine, = -1.
Minimum inclindation of slope in degrees.
Maximum inclination of slope in degrees.
Position of the plot on land surface (e.g., Summit, shoulder, upper slope, middle slope, lower slope, toeslope, no slope, channel bed, dune swale, pond).
Landform type.

field.exampleComments: GARI044-2 is the unique observation separate code for plot GARI044. It has a previous observation of GARI044-1 (observation code). For this record in the loading table, no plot will be added, but just an observation. All fields that appear before authorObsCode will not be added to the VegBank module upon migration. These are plot fields that are already listed for the plot that GARI044-1 belongs to.

field.FieldDefinition: Code that refers to the AuthorObsCode (=AuthorPlotCode) of the previous observation.
Link to data from the previous observation of this plot.
Link between an observation and the project within which the observation was made
The date of the observation, or the first day if the observation spanned more than one day.
If the observation event spanned more than a single day, this is the last day on which observations were made.
Estimated accuracy of the observation date.
Lower diameter limit in centimeters for inclusion of a tree in the stem count (stemCount).

field.example1: We used the Smith-Peterson method to gather...
field.FieldDefinition: Additional metadata helpful for understanding how the data were collected during the observation event.

the total surface area (in m2) used for cover estimates and for which a complete species list is provided. If subplots were used, this would be the total area of the subplots without intersticial space.
Were cover values for the total taxon list collected from one contiguous area or dispersed subplots (e.g., continguous, dispersed-regular, dispered-random)?
TRUE indicates that taxonObservation.taxonCover was automatically calculated from the values of all stratumObservation.taxonStratumCover
the total surface area (in m2) observed for recording woody stem data
The method used to obtain basal area or tree stem data (e.g., full census, point quarter, random pairs, Bitterlich, other).
Location where the hard data reside and any access instructions.
This is the effort spent making the observations as estimated by the party that submitted the data (e.g., Very thorough, Average, Hurried description).

Quality of plot as determined by an automated filter system, including values such as (1) sufficient for determining type occurrence, (2) sufficient for inclusion in a classification revision, and (3) fully compliant with recommendations.
Subjective assessment of floristic quality by the party that submitted the plot (e.g., Highest, High, High but incomplete, Moderate, Moderate and incomplete, Low).

Subjective assessment of the taxonmic quality of the bryophye data by the party that submitted the plot (e.g., Highest, High, High but incomplete, Moderate, Moderate and incomplete, Low, Very incomplete,absent).

Subjective assessment of the taxonmic quality of the lichen data by the party that submitted the plot (e.g., Highest, High, High but incomplete, Moderate, Moderate and incomplete, Low, Very incomplete,absent).

field.example1: This site was particularly unusual for this area in that...
field.FieldDefinition: Additional unstructured observations useful for understanding the ecological attributes and significance of the plot observations.
Unstructured observations on the landscape context of the observed plot.
How homogeneous was the community (e.g., homogeneous, compositionial trend across plot, conspicuous inclusions, irregular mosaic or pattern).
Season expression of the community (e.g., typical growing season, vernal, aestival, wet, autumnal, winter, dry, irregular ephemerals present).

field.example1: plot is quite representative of surrounding stand
field.FieldDefinition: How representative was the plot of the stand?
Total basal area of woody stems (in m2/ha).
What is the hydrologic regime, which is a refelction of frequency and duration of flooding)?
How moist was the soil at the sampling event?
How well drained is the site (generally consistent with USDA classes)?
How saline is the water, if a flooded community?
For aquatic or marine vegetation, what was the water depth in m.
For aquatic or marine vegetation, what was the closest distance to shore in m.
Median depth to bedrockor permafrost in m (usually from averaging multiple probe readings).
Depth of the curficial organic layer, where present, in centimeters.
Percent of surface that is exposed bedrock.
Percent of surface that is exposed rock and gravel.
Percent of surface that is wood.
Percent of surface that is litter.
Percent of surface that is bare soil.
Percent of surface that is water.
Percent of surface that belong to an additional itemized category
Name of additional itemized groundcover category (e.g., beer cans).
How mature is the stand. Could be young, mature but even-aged, old-growth, etc.
Description of the assumed successional status of the plot. This descriptionis of necessity highly subjective.
Height of the tree layer in m.
Height of the shrub layer in m.
Height of the field layer in m.
Height of the nonvascular layer in m.
Height of the submerged layer in m.
Total cover of the tree layer in percent.
Total cover of the shrub layer in percent.
Total cover of the field layer in percent.
Total cover of the nonvascular layer in percent.
Total cover of the floating layer in percent.
Total cover of the submerged layer in percent.
Which of the six standard strata is dominant?
The predominant growth form?
The second-most predominant growthform?
The third-most predominant growthform
Total cover of the predominant growthform?
Total cover of the second-most predominant growthform?
Total cover of the third-most predominent growthform?
soil taxon within the USDA classification hierarchy, including Order, Suborder, Greatgroup, Subgroup, Family and Series.
How was the soil taxon determined (e.g., field observation, map, other sources)?
Code that will translate into a fk pointing to the specific party that made the contribution.
Code that will translate into a fk that identifies the role that the party had in the plot obsevation (e.g., PI, contact, research advisor, field assistant, taxonomist, owner, guide, etc.).
Code that will translate into a fk pointing to the specific party that made the contribution.
Code that will translate into a fk that identifies the role that the party had in the plot obsevation (e.g., PI, contact, research advisor, field assistant, taxonomist, owner, guide, etc.).
Code that will translate into a fk pointing to the specific party that made the contribution.
Code that will translate into a fk that identifies the role that the party had in the plot obsevation (e.g., PI, contact, research advisor, field assistant, taxonomist, owner, guide, etc.).
Code that will translate into a fk pointing to the specific party that made the contribution.
Code that will translate into a fk that identifies the role that the party had in the plot obsevation (e.g., PI, contact, research advisor, field assistant, taxonomist, owner, guide, etc.).
Code that will translate into a fk pointing to the specific party that made the contribution.
Code that will translate into a fk that identifies the role that the party had in the plot obsevation (e.g., PI, contact, research advisor, field assistant, taxonomist, owner, guide, etc.).
Quadrangle in which the plot is located
County in which the plot is located
State/Province in which the plot is located
Country in which the plot is located
Continent in which the plot is located

field.exampleComments: stratum1 to stratum 9 are up to 9 different strata defined for each plot. These can be reference via Cover Data (using the same number stratum there for the stratum defined here for that plot), or in Stratum Cover, where you reference a stratum using its stratumIndex (which must be listed in one of stratumIndex1-stratumIndex9 in this table)
field.FieldDefinition: This attribute will link to the definition of the specific stratum observed.
Average height to the top of the stratum in meters.
Average height of the bottom of the stratum in meters.
Cover of the vegetation within the given stratum in percent.
This attribute will link to the definition of the specific stratum observed.

table.TableDescription: This table contains data about the taxa observed on a plot and their relative covers, as well as specimen information.
table.TableReqd: At least one of the following is required: Cover Data, Stratum Cover Data, Stem Data. These are the three different options for referencing the plant taxa on your plot.

field.FieldDefinition: Database generated identifier assigned to each unique taxon observation.
Author's Plot number/code, or the original plot number if taken from literature.

field.exampleComments: you can reference a plantName that isn't in your species list. Here, Pinus pungens will be looked up in the USDA directly from here. If this name can't be found, an error will be reported and you will have to either define a new concept (and add it to the Species List table) or match this to an extant plant concept in the vegbank module.
field.FieldDefinition: A unique code that will refer to a plant concept consistently throughout the loading processes.
Specifics about the accession number and location of a collection made of the taxon

field.exampleComments: percentage used directly
field.FieldDefinition: Overall cover of the taxon across all strata

field.exampleComments: cover class used, will be converted to percent using coverMethod you supply
field.FieldDefinition: Overall cover of the taxon across all strata, using a Cover Code from CoverIndex table
Total basal area of the species in the stemInferenceArea in m2/ha

field.exampleComments: supersample used for this particular species
field.FieldDefinition: This is the area in m2 used to infer the cover of a given taxon. Generally this should be equal to observation.taxonInferenceArea, but at times this area may be larger or smaller for a specific taxon.

field.exampleComments: cover class used of the same cover method as mentioned above
field.FieldDefinition: Percent cover of taxon in stratum, using a Cover Code from CoverIndex table

field.exampleComments: cover class used of the same cover method as mentioned above
field.FieldDefinition: Percent cover of taxon in stratum, using a Cover Code from CoverIndex table
Percent cover of taxon in stratum, using a Cover Code from CoverIndex table
Percent cover of taxon in stratum, using a Cover Code from CoverIndex table

Percent cover of taxon in stratum, using a Cover Code from CoverIndex table
Percent cover of taxon in stratum
Percent cover of taxon in stratum

field.exampleComments: stratum percent directly used.
field.FieldDefinition: Percent cover of taxon in stratum
Percent cover of taxon in stratum
Percent cover of taxon in stratum

table.TableDescription: This table contains data about each species cover in each stratum on the plot.
table.TableReqd: At least one of the following is required: Cover Data, Stratum Cover Data, Stem Data. These are the three different options for referencing the plant taxa on your plot.

field.FieldDefinition: Database generated identifier assigned to each unique taxon-stratum observation.

field.exampleComments: This table's values will get moved to the Cover Data table before migration. This format is offered for ease of entry.
field.FieldDefinition: Author's Plot number/code, or the original plot number if taken from literature.
A unique code that will refer to a plant concept consistently throughout the loading processes.

field.exampleComments: this field must be exactly the same for each AuthorPlotCode-PLANTcode combination.
field.FieldDefinition: Specifics about the accession number and location of a collection made of the taxon

field.exampleComments: this field must be exactly the same for each AuthorPlotCode-PLANTcode combination.
field.FieldDefinition: Overall cover of the taxon across all strata

field.exampleComments: this field must be exactly the same for each AuthorPlotCode-PLANTcode combination.
field.FieldDefinition: Overall cover of the taxon across all strata, using a Cover Code from CoverIndex table

field.exampleComments: this field must be exactly the same for each AuthorPlotCode-PLANTcode combination.
field.FieldDefinition: Total basal area of the species in the stemInferenceArea in m2/ha

field.exampleComments: this field must be exactly the same for each AuthorPlotCode-PLANTcode combination.
field.FieldDefinition: This is the area in m2 used to infer the cover of a given taxon. Generally this should be equal to observation.taxonInferenceArea, but at times this area may be larger or smaller for a specific taxon.
References a StratumIndex (1-9) in Z_USER_C_PlotData for this plot to link this stratum to the stratum definitions that table.
Percent cover of taxon in stratum, using a Cover Code from CoverIndex table
Percent cover of taxon in stratum

table.TableDescription: This table contains data about the stems that you measured on the plot.
table.TableReqd: At least one of the following is required: Cover Data, Stratum Cover Data, Stem Data. These are the three different options for referencing the plant taxa on your plot.

field.FieldDefinition: Database generated identifier assigned to each unique stem observation.
Author's Plot number/code, or the original plot number if taken from literature.
A unique code that will refer to a plant concept consistently throughout the loading processes.

field.exampleComments: the 37.5cm Pinus pungens is probably a stem size class (35-40) that has been converted to VegBank standard (size and accuracy)
field.FieldDefinition: The diameter of the stem in centimeters. When diameter classes are used, the stemDiameter is the midpoint between the low end and high end for the diameter class; the offset between this and the endpoints is stored in the stemDiameterAccuracy attribute.
The accuracy of the stem diameter measurements in centimeters. This represents the distance between the diameter class midpoint and endpoint.

The measured height of the stem in meters. When height classes are used, the stemHeight is the midpoint between the low end and high end for the height class; the offset between this and the endpoint is stored in the stemHeightAccuracy field.
The accuracy of the measured height of a stem, being the offset between the midpoint of the class and the endpoint, in meters.

field.exampleComments: 3 stems for the 37.5cm P. pungens cover class, others are individual stems (count=1)
field.FieldDefinition: The number of stems of a single species that have these specific stem diameter and height data in common.

field.exampleComments: This field references only one stem, so stemCount field should be 1 if these values are filled out. A comma separated list of coordinates in NOT acceptable. If you have coordinates for each stem, create a record in this table for each stem.
field.FieldDefinition: Name or code applied to a specific stem in the plot. This is generally a numeric label to associate a fielddata entry with a stem in the database.
The X-coordinate of the stem position in m. The user will enter the relative position of stems with respect to the plot origin (in meters) with the x-axis defined by the plot azimuth.
The Y-coordinate of the stem position, as above.
The value of the user-defined variable.
The value of the user-defined variable.
The value of the user-defined variable.
The value of the user-defined variable.
The value of the user-defined variable.
The value of the user-defined variable.
The value of the user-defined variable.

table.TableDescription: This table contains soils data about the soils collected from a plot.

field.FieldDefinition: Database generated identifier assigned to each unique soil observation.
Author's Plot number/code, or the original plot number if taken from literature.
The horizon to which this observation applies.

field.exampleComments: this field is in meters
field.FieldDefinition: The depth at which the horizon observation starts.
The depth at which the horizon observation ends.
Soil color (USDA guidelines recommended).
Percent organic content of the soil (for methods see observation.methodsNarrative).
Soil texture class.
Percent sand in the soil hoizon.
Percent silt in the soil horizon.
Percent clay in the soil horizon.
percent coarse fragments in the soil, prior to removal for textural analysis
pH of the soil (for methods see observation.methodsNarrative).
Cation exchange capacity (for methods see observation.methodsNarrative).
Percent base saturation (for methods see observation.methodsNarrative).
Text description of the soil.

field.exampleComments: user defined fields for chemical analysis, which differ from lab to lab
field.FieldDefinition: The value of the user-defined variable.

table.TableDescription: This table contains data about evidence of disturbance observed on the plot.

field.FieldDefinition: Database generated identifier assigned to each unique disturbance observation.
Author's Plot number/code, or the original plot number if taken from literature.
The type of disturbance being reported

field.exampleComments: an observation of lack of distrubance can be accepted, if this is significant
field.FieldDefinition: Intensity or degree of the disturbance.
Estimated time in years since the disturbance event.
Percent of the plot that experienced the event.

field.example1: no wind damage seen here, which is quite extraordinary. Adjacent areas damaged.
field.example2: The fire was a human disturbance, not natural.
field.FieldDefinition: Text description of details of the disturbance and its impact on the vegetation.

table.TableDescription: This table contains data about your community concepts that you would like to either 1) add to VegBank as new concepts and/or 2) add your party perspective to concepts.
table.TableReqd: This table is required only if you have new community concepts to add to VegBank.

field.exampleComments: This table is the same setup as Species List
field.FieldDefinition: The User's code for a community. A code that uniquely identifies a community in your other loading tables (Plot Community)

field.exampleComments: 1:admittedly this is a weird community concept - just a fictional example, 2: CEGL007299 is the official name for HERO-NC which is a shortcut code for the user (High Elevation Red Oak Forest, North Carolina)
field.FieldDefinition: The widely-recognized code/name for a community. This field is the foreign key into the commName table.

field.exampleComments: 2: no further information is necessary for example 2, because the user's code has been referenced to a recognized community in the NVC (if NVC codes are included in your vegbank module). Example 2 matches a user's internal code to a widely known code, example 1 defines a new community concept.
field.FieldDefinition: This is the name of the classification system wherein the name is applied (e.g., Scientific, Spanish common).
Status of the concept by the party (accepted, not accepted, undetermined)
This field is the foreign key into the commName table.
This is the name of the classification system wherein the name is applied (e.g., Scientific, Spanish common).
Status of the concept by the party (accepted, not accepted, undetermined)
This field is the foreign key into the commName table.
This is the name of the classification system wherein the name is applied (e.g., Scientific, Spanish common).
Status of the concept by the party (accepted, not accepted, undetermined)
This field is the foreign key into the commName table.
This is the name of the classification system wherein the name is applied (e.g., Scientific, Spanish common).
Status of the concept by the party (accepted, not accepted, undetermined)

field.example1: Bobs' guide to weird Kansas communities
field.FieldDefinition: Foreign key into the Reference table to identify a reference in which the community was identified by a name. This could be a regular publication, or a self reference created by completing the commDescription field in commReference

field.example1: Bobs' guide to weird Kansas communities
field.FieldDefinition: Foreign key into commReference to identify the source of the name.

field.example1: This piney woodland has a strong Arbutus understorey
field.FieldDefinition: The conceptDescription is a description of the community concept by the party that contributed the concept.
The commLevel attribute specifies a level in the taxonomic hierarcy to which a class belongs.

The commParent is a recursive key to the concept of the parent level in the classification hierarchy. For example, if this concept were at the association level, the parentClass would be a concept that is the parent alliance type.
Status of the concept by the party (accepted, not accepted, undetermined)

field.example1: There are many examples of this community in neighboring...
field.FieldDefinition: Comments by party providing rationale for status assignment

field.exampleComments: II.A.4.N.a is the formation for "Rounded-crowned temperate or subpolar needle-leaved evergreen woodland" which is the formation under which this new community would belong
field.FieldDefinition: This is the foreign key into the communityConcept table "pointing" to a concept recognized by the party as a "standard" concept.

field.exampleComments: "less than" refers to the new concept being narrower than the synonym here referenced.
field.FieldDefinition: This is the descriptive attribute that is used to relate the congruence between two concepts.
This is the foreign key into the communityConcept table "pointing" to a concept recognized by the party as a "standard" concept.
This is the descriptive attribute that is used to relate the congruence between two concepts.
This is the foreign key into the communityConcept table "pointing" to a concept recognized by the party as a "standard" concept.
This is the descriptive attribute that is used to relate the congruence between two concepts.
This is the foreign key into the communityConcept table "pointing" to a concept recognized by the party as a "standard" concept.
This is the descriptive attribute that is used to relate the congruence between two concepts.

table.TableDescription: This table assigns plots to particular communities (up to 4 per record), based on a methodology that you specify.
table.TableReqd: Not required. Only necessary if you wish to assign plots to communities.

field.FieldDefinition: Database generated identifier assigned to each unique plot community classification.
Author's Plot number/code, or the original plot number if taken from literature.
Start date for the application of a vegetation class to a plot observation by one or more parties.

field.exampleComments: 1: the first community interpretation stops when the user interprets the plot again to a new community that did not exist when the first interpretation was done, 2: the second interpretation is still current - has no stop date
field.FieldDefinition: Stop date for the application of a vegetation class to a plot observation by one or more parties.
Classification informed by simple inspection of data.
Classification informed by inspection of floristic composition tables.
Classification informed by use of multivariate numerical tools.
Classification informed by use of automated expert system.
Notes about the classification event by the parties participating in the event. This might include the purpose or rationale for the classification.

field.exampleComments: 2: name references commCode in Community Concept table
field.FieldDefinition: CommName that is used in Z_USER_H_CommNames to identify a CommName_ID, which is the foreign key into CommName table.
Indicates the degree of fit with the community concept being assigned (e.g., fits concept well, fits but not typal, possible fit, just outside concept).

field.exampleComments: 1: high confidence that this Community (CEGLWWWWWW) is a poor fit for this plot (observation)
field.FieldDefinition: Indicates the degree of confidence of the interpretor(s) in the interpretation made. This can reflect the level of familiarity with the classification or the sufficiency of information about the plot (e.g., High, Moderate, Low).

field.example1: maybe the closest association, but doesn't really work
field.FieldDefinition: Notes pertaining to the classification analysis and decision.

field.exampleComments: CEGLZZZZZ = fictional CEGL code that is assumed to be found in the NVC
field.FieldDefinition: CommName that is used in Z_USER_H_CommNames to identify a CommName_ID, which is the foreign key into CommName table.
Indicates the degree of fit with the community concept being assigned (e.g., fits concept well, fits but not typal, possible fit, just outside concept).

Indicates the degree of confidence of the interpretor(s) in the interpretation made. This can reflect the level of familiarity with the classification or the sufficiency of information about the plot (e.g., High, Moderate, Low).

field.example1: doesn't seem to fit anything real
field.FieldDefinition: Notes pertaining to the classification analysis and decision.
CommName that is used in Z_USER_H_CommNames to identify a CommName_ID, which is the foreign key into CommName table.
Indicates the degree of fit with the community concept being assigned (e.g., fits concept well, fits but not typal, possible fit, just outside concept).

Indicates the degree of confidence of the interpretor(s) in the interpretation made. This can reflect the level of familiarity with the classification or the sufficiency of information about the plot (e.g., High, Moderate, Low).

field.example1: OK fit for this formation - but can't find a good alliance
field.FieldDefinition: Notes pertaining to the classification analysis and decision.
CommName that is used in Z_USER_H_CommNames to identify a CommName_ID, which is the foreign key into CommName table.
Indicates the degree of fit with the community concept being assigned (e.g., fits concept well, fits but not typal, possible fit, just outside concept).

Indicates the degree of confidence of the interpretor(s) in the interpretation made. This can reflect the level of familiarity with the classification or the sufficiency of information about the plot (e.g., High, Moderate, Low).
Notes pertaining to the classification analysis and decision.
Primary Party: Link to the party that contributed to the classification event.
Code that will translate into a fk that identifies the role that the party had in the classification event (e.g., classifier, consultant, research advisor).
Link to the party that contributed to the classification event.
Code that will translate into a fk that identifies the role that the party had in the classification event (e.g., classifier, consultant, research advisor).

table.TableDescription: This table stores data about what your user defined fields are measuring or describing.
table.TableReqd: Not required unless you have user defined data in one or more of the following: Plot Data, Cover Data, Stem Data, Soil Data.

field.FieldDefinition: Database generated identifier assigned to each unique user-defined metadata field.
The UserDefined_ID of this User-Defined Field that has been migrated into VegBank module.

field.exampleComments: F: for Soil Data loading table, referenced automatically with form
field.FieldDefinition: Identifies which Loading table the user-defined data is stored in. C = plotData, D=CoverData, E=StemData, F=SoilData

field.exampleComments: UserDef1 and UserDef2
field.FieldDefinition: Identifies the field in which user defined data is stored in a Loading table, 1-35.
Name of the user-defined variable.
Metadata about this user-defined variable.
Category of variable; included to facilitate queries for specific types of data.
Database data type of the user-defined variable.
Name of table with which this user-defined variable is associated. For example soilBHorizonColor may be defined by the data contributor as associated with the observation table.
